metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof "Considerable unreimbursed medical care is delivered through electronic patient portals: a retrospective review"

body_text.text: We conducted a retrospective review to assess patient-initiated messages on the online portal 37 used in the dermatology clinic at UT Southwestern Medical Center called "MyChart. and medical history questionnaires. The message type was verified, and medical advice requests 50 were reviewed independently by each author. Encounters where physicians managed the entire 51 patient complaint through the MyChart portal were considered as separate electronic E&M 52 services of the patient's concern utilizing the CMS guidelines and thus potentially eligible for 53 provider reimbursement. 54 55 There was a steady rise in patient-initiated MyChart encounters each year (Figure 1 ). Contact 56 hours and patient clinic encounters also rose during this same time period, but the rise in 57 messages outpaced the time spent in face-to-face care (Figure 2 ). In our sample, 58% of the 58 messages were medical advice requests and 30.75% of all messages met criteria for separate 59 E&M services via the portal. Other categories of messages included 22% for appointment 60 changes, 13.50% for history questionnaires, and 6.5% for medication refill requests. 88  89  90  91  92  93  94  95  96  97  98  99  100  101  102  103  104  105  106  107  108  109  110  111  112  113

FIGREF0.text: for all face-to-face clinic encounters and provider contact hours from 39 1/1/2010-12/31/2018 in general dermatology; patient-initiated MyChart messages were collected 40 for the same time period. Clinic encounters were calculated from the number of patients seen by 41 each provider per year. Provider contact hours were calculated as the sum of the hours of booked 42 appointments per year. Using a population of 30,770, the number of patients seen in general 43 dermatology annually, to obtain a 95% confidence level, confidence interval of +/-5%, and 44 standard deviation of 0.5, we calculated a sample size of 384, rounded to 400, utilizing the 45 Cochran formula to determine the number of messages needed to review. 2 These 400 MyChart 46 messages were randomly selected from all messages from 2010-2018 using a random numbers 47table to generate a list of stochastically selected messages to examine. Data was then classified 48 by message category: medical advice requests, medication refill requests, appointment changes, 49

FIGREF1.text: reimbursed virtual encounters since 2019. For instance, CPT 99421-99423 reimburses 63 for remote monitoring treatment management services for an established patient based on length 64 of time spent with the provider. 3 The reimbursement is currently suggested at $15 for 5-10 65 minutes, $30 for 11-20 minutes, and $50 for > 21 minutes. 4 Most follow-up general dermatology 66 clinic visits are billed with the CPT 99213 where providers may be reimbursed up to $150. A 67 large disparity exists between proposed reimbursements for virtual versus face-to-face 68 encounters that may carry the same level of liability and clinical decision-making. 69 70 Due to the 2019 Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19), effective March 6, 2020, CMS will pay 71 physicians for telehealth services at the same rate as in-office visits. 5 Our study supports 72 continuation of these policies after the social distancing measures of COVID-19 have ended.

FIGREF2.text: Patient MyChart encounters quantified -This figure shows the steady rise that was 141 seen in the number of patient-initiated MyChart encounters each year with a total increase Patient MyChart messages compared to provider contact hours and patient clinic 145 encounters -This figure shows the increase in patient initiated MyChart messages as compared 146 to provider contact hours and patient clinic encounters. The rise in messages outpaced the time 147 spent in face-to-face care.

TABREF0.text: Title: "Considerable unreimbursed medical care is delivered through electronic patient portals: a Elysha Kolitz, BA 1 , Austin Smith, BS 2 , Oliver Taylor, BS 1 , Melissa M. Mauskar, MD 3,4 , Heather Goff, University of Texas Health Science Center at San Antonio, 7703 Floyd Curl Dr., San Antonio, TX Department of Dermatology, University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, Dallas, TX, USA. Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, Dallas, Corresponding Author: Heather W. Goff, M.D. The Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health Act in 2009 required all 32 medical practices to transition to electronic medical records (EMRs) with integrated patient 33 communication portals. 1 Portals can be used for communication of test results, appointment 34 changes, or patient questions about new or existing medical complaints. 35
